channel.title: I had to take Comp Sci 1 before AP Comp Sci
channel.description:
So I'm taking a course on VB :(. I already know enough C++ and whatever so don't give me shit for not knowing VB please. But here's my problem, I have this code, and I want it to instead of clearing the entire form, to leave the blue circles that are there. Help please.
Public Class frmBox Dim g As Graphics = Me.CreateGraphics Dim q As Graphics = Me.CreateGraphics
Private Sub Form1_MouseClick(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs) Handles Me.MouseClick Dim recbox As Rectangle = New Rectangle(e.X, e.Y, 25, 25) q.FillEllipse(Brushes.Blue, recbox) End Sub
Private Sub Form1_MouseMove(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs) Handles Me.MouseMove Dim recbox As Rectangle = New Rectangle(e.X, e.Y, 25, 25) System.Threading.Thread.Sleep(50) g.Clear(Me.BackColor) g.FillEllipse(Brushes.Green, recbox) End Sub End Class

item.description:
@Uriko wrote:

Check the course curriculum yourself and take matters into your own hands.

It’s not like the teacher can be like “OMG DAT NOT VB U PROGIN IN, VIRUS”.

If the curriculum allows it, tell the teacher to fuck off and let you be.
[size=4pt]note: don’t tell her to fuck off[/size]

item.dc:creator: @phonnygoblin phonnygoblin
item.description:
@phonnygoblin wrote:

Our compilers can only run VB 2005. That’s it. And they’re all in a circle, so the teacher can see what we’re doing, and I don’t think she’d like me doing something to let me run other programs. I’ll ask, though(probably won’t).

item.source: I had to take Comp Sci 1 before AP Comp Sci

item.title: I had to take Comp Sci 1 before AP Comp Sci
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:6, topic:264310”][quote author=phonnygoblin link=topic=349046.msg2683794#msg2683794 date=1235531617]
I was told Timer’s only measure 18 times per second, not 1000 times :. And I get what you’re saying, but I have no idea how to do any of it. lol, I guess some googling is to be done. Thanks for the help, I’d rep if I could.
[/quote]
What do you mean timer’s can only measure 18 times per second? You set the interval in milliseconds, and there are 1000 milliseconds in a second of course. You will never be able to get down to 1000 times a second, The lowest I’ve had it reliably go is about 60 times a second. It’s just a limitation of how the OS’s scheduler works.

I was doing some benchmarks recently, and I set the timer interval to 17ms, or about 60 times a second, which it seems to be able to maintain reasonably well.[/quote]

~32 ~47 ~34 The Head and Shoulders Pattern.

This is the first time I’ve been able to put my research into Technical Analysis to real world use. I’m strangely satisfied.

Read full topic

item.source: I had to take Comp Sci 1 before AP Comp Sci

item.title: I had to take Comp Sci 1 before AP Comp Sci
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

What do you mean timer’s can only measure 18 times per second? You set the interval in milliseconds, and there are 1000 milliseconds in a second of course. You will never be able to get down to 1000 times a second, The lowest I’ve had it reliably go is about 60 times a second. It’s just a limitation of how the OS’s scheduler works.

I was doing some benchmarks recently, and I set the timer interval to 17ms, or about 60 times a second, which it seems to be able to maintain reasonably well.

Read full topic

item.source: I had to take Comp Sci 1 before AP Comp Sci

item.title: I had to take Comp Sci 1 before AP Comp Sci
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

The best way of doing this is spawning a thread and passing it a delegate method, which will be called after the new thread has slept for a specified time. So instead of blocking the UI thread, the sleep is done asynchronously.
Luckily, .NET has done this for us in the form of the System.Windows.Forms.Timer class

Read full topic
item.source: I had to take Comp Sci 1 before AP Comp Sci

item.title: I had to take Comp Sci 1 before AP Comp Sci
item.dc:creator: @phonnygoblin phonnygoblin
item.description:
@phonnygoblin wrote:

Nobody ever taught me anything :(. My teacher hasn’t even taught my class how to use if then statements. lol. I’ll try using OnPaint() I guess, but how else do I get a SCAR-styled “wait()” function? Thanks.

Read full topic
item.source: I had to take Comp Sci 1 before AP Comp Sci

item.title: I had to take Comp Sci 1 before AP Comp Sci
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

A lot of what you are doing is just a bad idea, regardless of the language.
You should only paint in, well, OnPaint()
You should never call Thread.Sleep() in a UI thread, EVER.
Do you realize that every time the user moves their mouse the program will freeze for 50 ms? That may not seem like much, but that event is fired many, many times throughout moving the mouse from point A to point B.

What you want to do is maintain a list of blue and a list of green circles that will be drawn in OnPaint(), then simply clear the list of green circles when you want them to disappear and call Invalidate().

I’m pulling this all from C# experience, but seeing as you are using VB.net it shouldn’t matter.

Read full topic
item.source: I had to take Comp Sci 1 before AP Comp Sci

item.title: I had to take Comp Sci 1 before AP Comp Sci
item.dc:creator: @phonnygoblin phonnygoblin
item.description:
@phonnygoblin wrote:

So I’m taking a course on VB :(. I already know enough C++ and whatever so don’t give me shit for not knowing VB please. But here’s my problem, I have this code, and I want it to instead of clearing the entire form, to leave the blue circles that are there. Help please.

Public Class frmBox
Dim g As Graphics = Me.CreateGraphics
Dim q As Graphics = Me.CreateGraphics

Private Sub Form1_MouseClick(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs) Handles Me.MouseClick
    Dim recbox As Rectangle = New Rectangle(e.X, e.Y, 25, 25)
    q.FillEllipse(Brushes.Blue, recbox)
End Sub

Private Sub Form1_MouseMove(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs) Handles Me.MouseMove
    Dim recbox As Rectangle = New Rectangle(e.X, e.Y, 25, 25)
    System.Threading.Thread.Sleep(50)
    g.Clear(Me.BackColor)
    g.FillEllipse(Brushes.Green, recbox)
End Sub

End Class

Read full topic
